title-group.article-title: Organizational Aspirations, Reference Points, and Goals
title-group.subtitle: Building on the Past and Aiming for the Future

author-notes.corresp: George A. Shinkle, Australian School of Business, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia Email: g.shinkle@unsw.edu.au

abstract.p: Three distinct frameworks have been advanced by scholars to analyze organizational aspirations: behavioral theory, Ansoff’s strategic management view, and strategic reference point theory. These frameworks, or views, are grounded in different assumptions and mechanisms. This article reviews and synthesizes the three views, also drawing on literatures in economics, performance measurement, and psychology, to present a comprehensive understanding of organizational aspirations. This review shows the literature consists primarily of studies using behavioral theory explanations, typically provides studies of the consequences of theoretically inferred aspiration levels, is impoverished in terms of field measurement of aspirations, and lacks comparative or integrative studies of the three views. Drawing on this critique, the article identifies theoretical and empirical gaps and provides guidance for future research.

body.p: The strategic behavior of firms is guided by the discrepancy between aspiration and performance (Ansoff, 1979; Cyert & March, 1963; Fiegenbaum, Hart, & Schendel, 1996). Organizational aspirations are desired performance levels in specific organizational outcomes and have also been called goals and reference points. While there are numerous theories that provide directional guidance on specific goals, such as the resource-based view that recommends building competencies (Barney, 1991), there are three distinct analytical frameworks to explain organizational aspirations that comprehensively characterize both antecedents and consequences. These frameworks, or views, are founded on different assumptions and propose different relationship mechanisms. The first, behavioral theory, is based on concepts from the Carnegie School, specifically, bounded rationality, satisficing, search, adaptive learning, and sequential attention (Cyert & March, 1963; March & Simon, 1958). The second, Ansoff’s strategic management view, is based on forward-looking, goal-seeking, and analytical planning behavior (Ansoff, 1979, 1987) and strategic choice theory (Child, 1972). The third, strategic reference point theory (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996), is also founded on strategic choice concepts regarding antecedents, but relies on prospect theory for predicting outcomes (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). Though much has been learned, the differences in the research traditions underpinning these views have resulted in disconnected literatures. This has inhibited the development of a comprehensive understanding of the two foundational questions:

list-item.p: In what ways do aspirations influence strategic behaviors?

body.p: Given both the practical and theoretical importance of organizational aspirations, it is surprising that no comprehensive review of this research domain has been published. This article addresses that omission by evaluating the similarities and differences between the three views, compiling a comprehensive understanding of predicted relationships, and identifying theoretical and empirical gaps in the literature to guide future research.

Organizational aspirations, frequently referred to as goals, are central to strategic decision making. Setting goals and objectives is a long-standing component of scientific management (e.g., Taylor, 1911) and strategic planning (e.g., Ansoff, 1984; Chandler, 1962; Hofer & Schendel, 1978). Managers establish organizational goals to communicate strategic direction (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996), enhance performance (Carver & Scheier, 1981; Eisenhardt, 1985; Hamel & Prahalad, 1989), and provide measures of success (R. S. Kaplan & Norton, 1996a, 1996b, 2001; Meyer, 2002). The literature generally treats aspirations, goals, and reference points as similar concepts. While some scholars view these concepts as unique (e.g., Diecidue & Van de Ven, 2008), we do not, following Mezias, Chen, and Murphy (2002: 1285), who state, “There is a great deal of conceptual and empirical convergence between aspiration levels and other terms such as target or goal.” Therefore, in this article, the concepts of aspirations, goals, and reference points all lie under the umbrella term—aspirations—which was adopted because of its prevalence in the literature. In certain cases, the other terms will appear, but only to be consistent with source literature. For completeness, we will, in a later section, review the definition of these terms within each theoretical view.

Our review process followed a five-step procedure to ensure consistent and thorough coverage of the literature.1 First, we identified organization-level aspirations as the phenomenon of interest. Second, we scanned articles for sources and citations. Third, we searched the titles, keywords, and abstracts of articles from the Web of Science (Thomson Reuters) and the Business Source Premier (EBSCO Publishing) databases for the keywords aspirations, goals, reference points, performance referents, performance feedback, and attainment discrepancy. We focused on articles published between 1980 and 2010, but also considered earlier seminal articles and books that underpin this literature. Fourth, we reviewed the abstracts to confirm relevance. Fifth, we categorized and assessed the articles. Sixth, to build a more complete understanding, we drew insights from the literatures of organizational psychology (goal-setting theory), performance feedback (strategic performance measurement and control theory), and economics (expectations). These literatures, although separate and distinct, offer important insights. The resultant review shows how aspirations explain organizational behavior—specifically strategic change and risk taking. The 72 articles we compiled are from 25 different journals, demonstrating the broad interest in and importance of organizational aspirations.

Over the course of the review, we identified five areas in which understanding is lacking. First, the literature lacks robust empirical evidence on the antecedents of aspirations. Most studies rely on the formal theoretical model of behavioral theory to infer aspiration levels. Of the 62 empirical articles, only 5 measure the aspirations of firms in situ. Furthermore, 3 of these 5 studies come from the entrepreneurship literature. Even though strategic choice scholars have argued for an expanded set of antecedents including internal, external, and time factors (Ansoff, 1979; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996), studies using those theoretical views remain underrepresented. Second, although there are numerous empirical studies on the consequences of financial performance aspirations (e.g., ROS and ROA), studies of other aspirations are lacking. Early researchers used aspirations to explain risky choices of firms (Bromiley, 1991; Fiegenbaum & Thomas, 1988). More recently, researchers have studied a broad set of strategic behaviors, including, for example, illegal behavior (Mishina, Dykes, Block, & Pollock, 2010), search (Chen & Miller, 2007), and learning (J. A. C. Baum & Dahlin, 2007), as well as nonfinancial performance categories like size and growth (J. R. Baum & Locke, 2004; Greve, 2008). Third, while it is widely accepted that organizational aspirations influence strategic behavior, the moderators of the aspiration–consequence relationship are understudied (Greve, 2003c; Shimizu, 2007; Short & Palmer, 2003; Vissa, Greve, & Chen, 2010). Fourth, researchers are only beginning to attempt to integrate concepts and frameworks from other theories (Audia & Brion, 2007; Mishina et al., 2010). Finally, to our knowledge, there are no comparative or integrative studies of the three views. This gap limits our ability to comment on two crucial issues: Which mechanisms have the highest explanatory power, and on what factors are they contingent? Overall, these observations indicate an active research area where key questions remain unanswered.

This review contributes to the management literature in two ways. First, we review and synthesize the organizational aspirations literature across the three views—behavioral, Ansoffian strategic management, and strategic reference point. This allows us to both identify the distinctiveness of each view and compile a comprehensive understanding of aspiration relationships. Second, we propose a research agenda to aid scholarly inquiry. This agenda encourages scholars to (a) study the simultaneous and interactive effects of the factors indicated in the literature, (b) consider heterogeneity of firms in terms of aspiration determination and response, and (c) conduct comparative investigations of the three views.

In this article, we first present the theoretical foundations underpinning the three views. Then, we review current understanding, examining the literature from 1980 through 2010. Our guiding assumption is that the overall understanding of organizational aspirations is captured in the antecedent, consequence, and moderator relationships across the three theoretic views. Finally, we identify research opportunities.

sec.title: Organizational Aspirations: Theory Foundations
sec.p: The three analytical frameworks, or views, have different theoretical foundations, premises, and assumptions; thus, they provide different predictions of aspiration levels and provide different mechanisms to predict their consequences. These differences are examined in this section and are summarized in Table 1. First, an important aspect of behavioral theory, that is not shared by the other two views, is that decision makers in an organization are boundedly rational and satisficing (Cyert & March, 1963; March & Simon, 1958; Simon, 1955). Furthermore, behavioral theorists argue organizations adjust their aspirations based on past experience (Cyert & March, 1963). Lant and Shapira (2008: 60) state, “A key assumption of the behavioral theory of the firm is that firms adjust their behavior in response to their experience rather than acting on their expectations of future states of the world.” In contrast, both strategic approaches to organizational aspirations, Ansoff’s strategic management view and strategic reference point theory, assume that firms are forward-looking and adopt formal planning processes. Ansoff (1979: 165) states, “[A] principal input to rational aspirations are the future performance expectations.” Similarly, Fiegenbaum et al. (1996: 227), in discussing strategic reference point theory, state, “Today’s strategic choices can thus be heavily affected by . . . the future (where firms would like to be).” To summarize, a core premise of behavioral theory is that past performance shapes strategic behavior, which in turn influences future performance. The analogous premise of both strategic approaches is that future-based strategic choice behavior determines subsequent performance.

sec.p: Despite the fundamental differences among the three views, they have important similarities. All agree performance is influenced by strategic behavior and aspirations are a critical factor in determining strategic behavior. In general, organizations are expected to “act in order to enhance their degree of success in achieving their aspirations” (Lant, 1992: 624). Performance relative to aspirations is widely acknowledged to influence the intensity of behaviors, as well as the strategies undertaken (e.g., Ansoff, 1979; Cyert & March, 1963). Although aspirations and reference points draw on different theoretical foundations, each establishes a desired performance level for the organization and uses that level as a critical point when comparing organizational outcomes (Ansoff, 1979; Cyert & March, 1963; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). If performance is judged as below aspirations, firms are expected to select new strategies to increase performance (Cyert & March, 1963). These new strategies are generally assumed to involve increased risk (Bromiley, 1991). In addition to these similarities in consequences, there are also cases of overlap among the predicted antecedent factors that determine organizational aspirations. For example, all three views recognize historical performance as an antecedent to aspiration levels and assume organizations, or more precisely their managers, learn from experience. We build on these differences and similarities, below, as we review each theoretical framework.

sec.title: Behavioral Theory View
sec.p: Cyert and March (1963) specify organizational aspiration relationships in their work on the behavioral theory of the firm—as “aspiration theory” (Argote & Greve, 2007). Cyert and March differentiate between goal dimensions that define what is important to the organization and aspiration levels that define the target performance for a specific goal dimension. Cyert and March (1963: 115) identify three antecedents to goal dimensions and three antecedents to aspiration levels. The former are “the composition of the organizational coalition, the organizational division of labor in decision making, and the definition of problems facing the organization.” The latter are “the organization’s past goal, the organization’s past performance, and the past performance of other ‘comparable’ organizations” (Cyert & March, 1963: 115). Past goals and performance are discussed by Simon (1955) and, subsequently, formally linked to organizational aspiration levels by March and Simon (1958). Firms are expected to establish an aspiration based on “a weighted function of” the past goal, past performance, and past performance of others (Cyert & March, 1963: 115). The latter two factors are also referred to as historical (self) and social aspiration levels (e.g., Greve, 1998; Massini, Lewin, & Greve, 2005). Failing to achieve an aspiration is theorized to prompt problemistic search that results in organizational change. Therefore, organizational change occurs more frequently when performance is below, rather than above, the aspiration level. When performance is above the aspiration level, firms are expected to continue the status quo (Bromiley, Miller, & Rau, 2001), avoid actions that might result in performance below aspirations (March & Shapira, 1987), and strive for slightly higher performance (Cyert & March, 1963).

The behavioral explanation of aspirations is also linked to models of learning, search, and sequential attention to goals. First, organizational learning theory assumes current aspirations are a function of the previous period’s performance and are changed based on experience (Levinthal & March, 1981; Mezias & Glynn, 1993), or learning. Organizational behavior is goal directed, history dependent, and rule based (Levitt & March, 1988), with adaptation occurring through simple rule-based routines. Second, search processes are initiated when aspirations are unmet. Within this analytical framework, search is motivated by the problem of unmet aspirations, is simpleminded, and is biased. The intensity of search is dependent on “the extent to which goals are achieved and the amount of organizational slack” (Cyert & March, 1963: 116). Search is less rule based than simple adaptation. Third, where there are competing goals, sequential attention to goals explains how organizational responses to goal attainment depend on whether other goals are met (Greve, 2008).

The behavioral theory developed by Cyert, March, Simon, and their colleagues has been extended and developed into a major research stream. For example, although March and Simon (1958) argue that managers judge performance versus aspirations as either a success or a failure, subsequent researchers have replaced this dichotomous choice with a continuum that is contingent on the magnitude of the performance–aspiration discrepancy (Bromiley, 1991; Greve, 1998). sec.title: Ansoff’s Strategic Management View
sec.p: The Ansoffian view of aspirations assumes managers make choices for their organization and organizations are environment-serving. Ansoff’s (1979: 10) framework, different from behavioral theory, examines the level of environmental turbulence and the aggressiveness of strategic managers. Within this framework, managers adapt aspirations in response to changes in internal or external factors, such as environmental conditions and future performance expectations. Ansoff (1984) later extended his framework to include the responsiveness of the organization’s capability (ability to adapt capability). In the Ansoffian view, executives are heterogeneous decision makers, selecting aspirations on a continuum of aggressiveness from satisfice to maximize, with goal seeking defined as the midrange on this continuum. In contrast to behavioral theory, Ansoff (1979) argues the majority of for-profit firms are goal-seeking rather than satisficing.2 His framework encompasses numerous factors that include, but are not limited to, past aspirations, performance, the external environment, historical traditions (values, routines, and inherited attributes), inertia, organizational capabilities, ambitions of controlling power groups, organizational stakeholders, and “managerial perceptions of need” (Ansoff, 1979: 117; Ansoff, 1987: 511). Managerial perceptions of need are explained by Ansoff (1979) to encompass managerial processing of inputs from internal and external environments. This perception is modeled as an interaction between managerial capability and openness of the managerial culture to information that departs from past-based expectations. Current literature refers to this perception as cognition (Eisenhardt & Zbaracki, 1992).

In the Ansoffian view, different strategic approaches can be selected to achieve a particular unmet aspiration. Deciding what specific action to take involves a choice of strategic thrust (Ansoff, 1979: 65). Ansoff offers five levels of strategic thrust: stable, reactive, anticipating, exploring, and creative. The exploring and creative levels are treated as discontinuous because they involve radical departures from past choices. In practice, the choice among the five levels is based on the aspiration-performance gap, external environment, internal capabilities, culture, and leadership, among other criteria (Ansoff, 1979: 113). Ansoff further purports firms increase performance in three ways. They (a) match strategic aggressiveness to the level of environmental turbulence, (b) match responsiveness of capability to the aggressiveness of strategy, and (c) design the components of capability to be supportive of each other (Ansoff, 1984; Moussetis, 2011). In general, managers are expected to select aspirations and strategic thrusts to pursue long-term, advantageous, strategic positions.

sec.title: Strategic Reference Point Theory
sec.p: Strategic reference point theory (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996) builds on prospect theory (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979) and Fiegenbaum and Thomas’s (1986, 1988) extension of prospect theory to include organization-level, rather than individual-level, considerations.3 It argues that managers of firms purposefully select aspirations to focus the attention of organization members on desired performance targets (see Panagiotou, 2007, for a historical review of reference theory). Firms are risk averse when their performance is above (better than) the strategic reference point and risk taking when performance is below (worse than) the strategic reference point (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). This is, in part, because managers will frame issues as threats, when above their reference point, or opportunities, when below their reference point. Managers determine reference points through considerations of internal capability, external conditions, and time. Internal capabilities include both strategic inputs (organizational capabilities, functions, value-added activities) and strategic outputs (results of the firm’s operations). External conditions include competitors’, customers’, and stakeholders’ influences. The time dimension includes both the past (organizational learning and identity) and the future (strategic intent).

Strategic reference point theory bases its arguments around three sets of factors, drawing on various theories that provide prescriptions for the selection of specific goals or reference points. These theories include, but are not limited to, motivation theory, the resource-based view, industrial economics, resource dependence, institutional theory, corporate identity, and strategic intent. Firms that continuously adapt their aspirations to changes in internal and external conditions and exhibit higher consensus on those reference points are predicted to achieve high performance. In addition to establishing reference points, strategic managers also make complementary interventions such as restructuring, reallocating resources, and redesigning reward systems to influence outcomes (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). These interventions are performed to change the mental maps and schemata of organizational members to realize target performance levels (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). These interventions moderate the aspiration–consequence relationship. This view of active strategic management is similar to management control theory, in which managers influence worker motivation by using organizational goals as performance reference points (Campion & Lord, 1982; Carver & Scheier, 1981; Eisenhardt, 1985; Klein, 1989).

sec.title: Levels, Discrepancies, and Strengths of Aspirations
sec.p: Extant literature studies aspirations in three different ways: performance levels, discrepancies, and commitment levels. First, the level of an aspiration is the target performance (e.g., 15% return on assets). Second, performance attainment discrepancy identifies the gap between performance and aspiration level—mathematically, performance minus aspiration (Lant, 1992; Lant & Montgomery, 1987). Researchers use the terminology “social/historical attainment discrepancy” or “social/historical comparison” to represent this gap measure (we use these terms interchangeably). Third, commitment to accomplish a goal gauges the strength of an aspiration (Cavusgil & Nevin, 1981; Overby, 2007). In other words, the strength of an aspiration reflects the priority or importance among other aspirations (goal priority has a long history; see Kellermanns, Walter, Lechner, & Floyd, 2005; Taylor, 1911). Behavioral theory, though silent on commitment, indicates organizations allocate attention sequentially among multiple goals, assuming implicitly that prioritization may exist. While strategic reference point theory is also silent on commitment to resolve the performance–aspiration gap, Ansoff’s (1979) view considers both the aggressiveness of aspirations and the vigor (commitment) with which they are pursued (for an elaboration on priority, see Ansoff, 1984). Through our review, we distinguish among aspiration levels (generally called aspirations), attainment discrepancies (performance comparisons), and strengths of aspirations.

sec.title: Organizational-Level and Managerial-Level Considerations
sec.p: This study focuses on aspirations at an organizational level. However, the literature frequently discusses organizational aspirations as a managerial-level construct. Organizational decision makers “select,” explicitly or implicitly, the aspirations for an organization. We do not contest the validity of this, but for the purpose of our study we assume managers “process” the factors influencing aspirations through their own cognitive sense making (Kiesler & Sproull, 1982), ultimately combining them through organizational processes to represent organization-level perspectives (Crossan, Lane, & White, 1999). In this way, the individual aspirations of top managers and the aspirations of organizations are inextricably linked, but not necessarily aligned (for further clarification, see Ansoff, 1979; Crossan et al., 1999; Greve, 2003c; and Schilling, Vidal, Ployhart, & Marangoni, 2003). In sum, we view attributions to decision makers in the literature as representing the organization’s perspective.

sec.title: Current Understanding: Antecedents, Consequences, and Moderators
sec.p: In this section, we update the theoretical foundation with current literature by reviewing the factors and relationships that have both theoretical and empirical support. It is organized according to the well-established threefold framework—antecedents, consequences, and moderators (Haleblian, Devers, McNamara, Carpenter, & Davison, 2009; Short, 2009). We will often refer to Figure 1 and Table 2 (note that Figure 1 identifies factors with empirical evidence using symbols). Our review encompasses 10 theoretical articles, 62 empirical articles, and 4 books that contribute to the evolution of aspiration understanding. The predominant lens utilized in the empirical studies of aspirations is behavioral theory. Of the 62 empirical articles reviewed, 50 articles use behavioral theory as the foundational lens and 3 articles use strategic reference point theory, and Ansoff’s strategic management view is unrepresented. However, many of the factors considered in the behavioral studies are argued to be salient in the two strategic choice views. Thus, the research work is, in part, complementary across views.
