sec.title: Antecedents: What Factors Influence Organizational Aspirations?
sec.p: The empirical evidence concerning antecedents of aspirations has expanded beyond the three factors identified by behavioral theory. This is largely the result of researchers combining theories (e.g., behavioral and cognition) and extending behavioral theory. Empirical research in the strategic views is sparse, but it continues to confirm and expand antecedent factors (Jones & Kashlak, 2001; Panagiotou, 2007; Short & Palmer, 2003). In our review of antecedents, we first address extensions to behavioral theory and then consider performance, internal and external factors, and time, as depicted in Figure 1.

sec.title: Behavioral foundation extensions
sec.p: Numerous empirical studies utilize the formal mathematical model proposed by Cyert and March (1963), as previously discussed (see Table 2—theoretical approach, behavioral theory of the firm [BTOF]). Most studies focus on outcomes; therefore, they infer an aspiration level using industry median performance for the social comparison component. An exception to this is Mezias et al. (2002), who directly studied aspiration levels (also see Lant & Montgomery, 1987). Mezias et al. (2002) indicated previous aspiration, rather than attainment discrepancies, is the most important variable in predicting an aspiration level. This observation is particularly striking given that other aspiration studies do not include this factor that requires fine-grained, firm-level data.

Behavioral researchers have added two reference points based on empirical observations. The first, survival, extends the original view by proposing managers judge firm performance relative to one of two reference points—an aspiration level or a survival level (bankruptcy; March & Shapira, 1987, 1992; also specified in Ansoff, 1979: 223). The second, organizational slack, has long been recognized by researchers to be important. Iyer and Miller (2008) provide strong arguments and empirical indications that firms shift their attention among aspirations (social comparison), survival, and slack, depending on their performance. As a result of these two additional reference points, survival and slack, organizational financial health is indirectly identified as an antecedent to performance aspirations.

Researchers have also observed upward striving as a fourth possible reference point. Upward striving is the setting of aspiration levels higher than nominally expected in behavioral theory. Striving aspirations are a contentious issue. Bromiley (1991) added an adjustment factor of 1.05 for firms performing above their aspiration level in his study of corporate risk taking. While this adjustment approach is used in only a limited number of studies (e.g., Deephouse & Wiseman, 2000; Park, 2007), it is consistent with Cyert and March’s (1963: 34) statement: “[I]n the steady state, aspiration level exceeds achievement by a small amount.” In support of upward striving, Gooding, Goel, and Wiseman (1996) performed a study on American manufacturing firms and indicated aspirations were elevated above median performance. However, this elevation varied over time and across industries. In addition, Lant (1992) observed upward striving in her study of students in a simulation game. Conversely, Mezias et al. (2002) found no indication of upward striving in their study of banks. Drawing on the studies by Lant (1992) and Mezias et al. (2002), Massini et al. (2005: 1554) provocatively concluded that upward striving “cannot be applied to managers.” In a later study, Labianca, Fairbank, Andrevski, and Parzen (2009) showed that striving discrepancies motivate change. A striving discrepancy is defined as the gap between an organization’s current performance and the performance of those organizations it desires to be like in the future. Labianca et al. (2009) argued organizations frequently choose a new set of reference organizations in an effort to maintain motivation to improve, particularly in high-performing and innovative organizations. Although this study takes a behavioral stance, the arguments are consistent with the forward-looking, strategic intent aspects of the strategic choice views. The results regarding upward striving suggest context, industry, referent group, and overall strategy may be relevant in determining the presence and intensity of upward striving.

sec.title: Performance
sec.p: There is substantial evidence an organization’s past performance and the past performance of other comparable organizations influence aspirations. Researchers have separately considered these factors. However, it is unclear which factor dominates (J. A. C. Baum & Dahlin, 2007; Greve, 2003c). Mishina et al. (2010) favor social aspirations, while Audia and Brion (2007) favor historical aspirations. Iyer and Miller (2008) report equivalence. These different results appear conditional on industry, economic condition, time period, or selection of the social comparison group.

Both the behavioral and the strategic choice literatures focus heavily on reference groups for performance comparisons. The insight gained regarding such referents suggests firms use specific reference groups even though industry averages have significant explanatory power (e.g., Fiegenbaum & Thomas, 1995; Ketchen & Palmer, 1999; Lehner, 2000; Park, 2007; Short & Palmer, 2003). There is growing indication that similar organizations influence one another more than dissimilar organizations do (J. A. C. Baum, Rowley, Shiplov, & Chuang, 2005; Short & Palmer, 2003). For example, Massini et al. (2005) studied firms on the performance frontier and found innovative firms establish innovation aspirations in comparison to other innovative firms. This is in contrast to imitative, noninnovative firms that set aspiration levels at the population average. In a second example, Panagiotou (2007) found firms compare themselves to their strategic group, or the group’s leader.

sec.title: Internal and external factors
sec.p: Both behavioral and strategic choice studies are beginning to provide empirical evidence that internal and external factors influence organizational aspirations—moving beyond the formal model of Cyert and March (1963). Studies have already explored how economic conditions, organizational attributes, and resources affect aspirations. Gooding et al. (1996) indicated the influence of industry and economic conditions. Later, Short and Palmer (2003), who generally follow strategic reference point theory, showed organizational attributes (size and age) influence the selection of reference points. Their study was based on thematic content analysis of CEO letters to shareholders. Most recently, Audia and Greve (2006) argued that resources influence the choice of aspiration because they buffer threats to the organization. Interestingly, resource arguments in this behavioral study align with capability arguments of strategic reference point theory. In addition, the entrepreneurship literature indicates the influence of leadership (communicated vision) and self-efficacy (J. R. Baum & Locke, 2004).

sec.title: Time and adaptation
sec.p: In determining the level of an aspiration, the adjustment mechanism and time perspectives are important. In both strategic choice views, aspiration adjustment is based on (a) changes to input factors and future expectations and (b) constraints of past history and future strategic intent. Thus, experiential learning and revised strategic choices based on future expectations guide the selection of aspirations. In addition, the managerial capability to perceive the environment and other forces on aspirations is viewed as adapting over time, through experience.

The behavioral view utilizes a learning model that focuses on past performance. When performance is judged as above aspirations, the aspiration level will adjust upward, and when performance is judged as below aspirations, the aspiration level will adjust downward (Cyert & March, 1963). In such learning models, the aspiration level is an exponentially weighted average of past outcomes that depends on the rate at which aspirations adjust to self-experience and the experience of others (Denrell & March, 2001). Many studies have used computer simulation techniques to examine adjustment and learning rates (see Table 2; e.g., Herriott, Levinthal, & March, 1985; Knudsen, 2008; Levinthal & March, 1981; March & Shapira, 1992). These simulation analyses aid understanding of aspiration behavior, particularly in aspiration adaptation (learning rates) on risk taking and performance (see internal and external moderator sections for implications).

In an empirical study of simulation game players, Lant (1992) found incremental adaptation better represented aspiration formation than a rational expectation model. She noted stability and ambiguity, in the context, may influence learning; aspiration adaptation processes depend on whether the context is conducive to accurate learning. In total, these studies indicate the simultaneous importance of time, context, and adjustment rates on aspirations.

sec.title: Consequences: What Outcomes Are Influenced by Aspirations?
sec.p: The consequences of aspiration attainment discrepancy have been studied across an array of individual industries and in numerous multi-industry studies, as shown in Table 2. The preponderance of these studies focus on strategic behaviors that are categorized by the level of organizational change or risk taking. However, scholars have recently begun considering a wider array of aspiration-influenced decisions, behaviors, and outcomes. In this section, we review the types of consequences attributed to aspiration attainment discrepancies, after first considering how aspirations influence outcomes.

sec.title: Aspiration–outcome relationships
sec.p: Performance relative to aspirations influences (a) the level of search and thus change in behavioral theory, (b) the level of risk taking in strategic reference point theory, and (c) the decision to choose a strategic thrust in the Ansoffian view. Overall, these views indicate higher aspiration attainment discrepancy motivates effort to be expended to reduce the discrepancy resulting in strategic action, change, or risk taking. However, there are exceptions. First, organizations close to failure generally exhibit risk aversion (Miller & Bromiley, 1990; Wiseman & Bromiley, 1996), but not always (Miller & Chen, 2004). Second, high levels of performance can lead to higher risk taking and change (Chen & Miller, 2007). This somewhat puzzling result has been explained by the limited threat of falling below aspirations (Bromiley et al., 2001), striving aspirations (Labianca et al., 2009), and high slack (Iyer & Miller, 2008). Third, in a provocative study, contrary to more than 50 years of research and 40 empirical studies, Denrell (2008) questions the strength of the effects of past performance on variable risk preferences. He uses simulations to show variations in risk taking can be interpreted as by-products of adaptation in an uncertain environment rather than the result of a deliberate choice motivated by variable risk preferences conditioned on aspirations. Beyond these noted exceptions, higher attainment discrepancy has generally been found to result in larger strategic change.

sec.title: Range of consequences studied
sec.p: An array of strategic behaviors, choices, and outcomes has been empirically studied as the consequence of aspiration attainment discrepancy. Figure 1 (see consequences) and Table 2 (see dependent variables) highlight examples. Although financial performance aspirations (e.g., ROS and ROA) are almost exclusively studied, aspirations are certainly not limited to financial performance. Several researchers have considered growth aspirations in relation to firm growth (J. R. Baum & Locke, 2004; Greve, 2008; Kolvereid, 1992; Wiklund & Shepherd, 2003). Furthermore, aspiration behavior has been generally viewed in relation to socially desirable outcomes (e.g., market entry, acquisitions, market search intensity, etc.). Recently, researchers have begun considering undesirable outcomes as well. For example, Harris and Bromiley (2007) studied financial misrepresentation and Mishina et al. (2010) studied illegal activities. As researchers broaden their exploration of aspiration consequences, they are finding unexpected implications.

sec.title: Moderators: What Factors Moderate the Aspiration–Consequence Relationship?
sec.p: Moderators of the aspiration–consequence relationship depend on the specific consequence under examination. Therefore, numerous moderating factors are potentially important. Our review categorizes empirically tested moderators as internal factors, external factors, and multiple aspirations.

sec.title: Internal moderators
sec.p: A limited number of studies include the influence of internal contingencies on aspiration–consequence relationships (excluding the topic of multiple aspirations, which is discussed later). Three studies support the importance of resources and capabilities, each in a different way. Miller and Leiblein (1996) forcefully argue the behavioral theory of the firm introduces slack as a moderator of organizational responses. They find indications, in their model of risk return, that risk is conceptualized as a function of performance attainment discrepancy (using aspiration theory). Wiklund and Shepherd (2003) studied small business growth and find resources, both human and financial capital, moderate the aspirations–growth relationship. Audia and Greve (2006) studied the conditions under which performance below the aspiration level leads to risk aversion. They find size, argued to be an indicator of resource stocks, moderates the aspiration attainment discrepancy–factory expansion relationship. Other moderators have been explored regarding specific consequences, such as operating experience and social legitimacy on risk taking (Desai, 2008), performance on growth (Greve, 2008), and organizational form and governance on search (Vissa et al., 2010). A separate stream of research, using simulations, indicates that the rate of aspiration adaptation may be a moderator. Denrell and March (2001), for example, show that slow adaptation leads to increased risk taking. March and Shapira (1992), in the same vein, indicate greater risk is taken with historical aspirations and slow adaptation or with social aspirations and fast adaptation. And Greve (2002) reports slow adaptation leads to higher performance.

sec.title: External moderators
sec.p: Five studies have found empirical support for environmental factors as moderators (also see the strategic consensus literature; e.g., Kellermanns et al., 2005). First, in a simulation model, Levinthal and March (1981: 307) studied adaptive organizational search and suggest the aspirations–consequences relationship may be “complicated by the confusions of a changing and autonomous environment.” They indicate environmental uncertainty, in conjunction with exogenous changes and learning rates, influences aspiration levels. Second, Gooding et al. (1996) indicate economic conditions across time, as well as industry, have moderating effects on the aspiration attainment discrepancy–risk taking relationship. Third, Deephouse and Wiseman (2000) find firms in turbulent environmental conditions, with performance both above and below aspirations, exhibit similar risk-taking behaviors. Two additional studies have indicated external factors: environmental opportunities (environmental dynamism) on growth (Wiklund & Shepherd, 2003) and reputational prominence on illegal activities (Mishina et al., 2010).

sec.title: Multiple aspirations as moderators
sec.p: In practice, firms have multiple aspirations (goals). Such aspirations will likely be of unequal importance since decision makers are expected to establish priorities for particular dimensions of performance (Ansoff, 1979; Cyert & March, 1963). The presence of multiple aspirations suggests they may conflict with one another (Ethiraj & Levinthal, 2009). In the behavioral view, shifting managerial attention focuses the organization on aspirations that are in danger of not being met (Greve, 2003c; Ocasio, 1997). In the Ansoffian strategic management view, aspirations have a priority in a hierarchy—a strength of aspiration. Across these views of multiple aspirations, there is the potential for a specific aspiration to interact with, or moderate the influence of, another.

Scholars generally agree that multiple aspirations interact, but only recently has a rigorous empirical exploration begun. Chen and Miller (2007), in their study on search intensity, suggest firms can attend to more than one goal. A year later, J. A. C. Baum et al. (2005) considered market share and network status aspirations, both historical and social, in their study of the propensity for nonlocal ties in investment banking. By interacting social and historical aspiration attainment discrepancies, they show the additive effect of aspiration discrepancies. Greve (2008) found insurance industry firms under imminent survival threats are primarily focused on performance goals. Other goals, such as organizational growth, are attended to only after the performance (survival) goal is satisfied. Labianca et al. (2009) studied how organizations attend to multiple aspiration discrepancies by considering simultaneous and sequential goal attention. Labianca et al. (2009: 443) conclude, “Some discrepancies have greater primacy and command more attention than others in certain situations. . . . If survival is not an immediate threat, decision-makers will take a broader perspective and will attend to multiple goals simultaneously.”

sec.title: Future Directions and Research Opportunities
sec.p: Our review elucidates a broad set of factors that have explanatory power in aspiration relationships. It indicates significant accomplishments in understanding the consequences of aspirations, predominantly using behavioral theory. It also highlights growing work on the antecedents of aspirations and relationship moderators. Nonetheless, there are crucial areas in need of development.

Three major areas of research opportunity emerged from our review. First, numerous factors have been theorized but remain untested, particularly in the underrepresented strategic choice views. Second, empirical studies have built on previous findings in limited ways because of data set constraints. As a result, we do not know which factors are most salient or how these factors may jointly influence aspiration relationships, particularly regarding antecedents of aspirations. Third, further considerations of firm-level heterogeneity may enhance the understanding of aspiration determination and response. We encourage the field to turn its attention toward increasing the explanatory power of the models by developing a deeper understanding of the simultaneous and interactive effects of the theorized and indicated factors on both aspirations and their consequences.

In presenting research opportunities, we begin by reviewing theoretical framing. Then we discuss antecedents, consequences, and moderators. We follow with considerations in aspiration adaptation and analysis. We end each section with a list of questions that have the potential to advance understanding. These questions are not intended to be exhaustive but rather to be a catalyst for deeper inquiry.

sec.title: Theoretical Framing
sec.p: There is value in integrating other theoretical perspectives with aspiration theories to address gaps in the current knowledge and increase the explanatory power of the resulting models. Researchers in the behavioral area suggest there is room to expand the theory (Greve, 2003c). Researchers in the strategic choice area suggest we need to understand extremes and the reasons for success, not just averages (Ansoff, 1979). However, there is a limit on the value of complexity. We, therefore, encourage scholars to evaluate the factors proposed in the comprehensive view, which has been compiled in Figure 1, to work toward a parsimonious model. For example, it is surprising behavioral theorists have yet to add more terms to Cyert and March’s (1963) formal model for aspiration levels. Such new terms have been acknowledged (e.g., Gooding et al., 1996), yet they have not been integrated into the formal model (see Sterman, 1988, for an example regarding expectations). Scholars should also consider comparative studies and cross-theoretical integrations. Doing so may provide increased understanding of heterogeneity in aspiration determination processes, aspiration levels, behavior, and performance.

sec.title: A consolidated view of aspirations?
sec.p: Some may wonder why this article does not propose a singular, integrated framework of organizational aspirations. The differences in the theoretical foundations, premises, and assumptions of the three views (see Table 1) make developing a singular framework problematic. This is particularly so, given the lack of comparative studies and field studies measuring aspiration levels that could potentially enable selection of the most predictive theoretical relationships. In the future, aspiration understanding may well evolve into an “open theory,” in a manner similar to individual goal-setting theory (Locke & Latham, 2006: 268), where new empirical discoveries can be readily integrated into a foundational model. A hint of this possible convergence lies in the evolution of behavioral theory (we are indebted to Philip Yetton for this insight). Behavioral theory was based on observations of managers in the 1950s and 1960s, when information limitations were far from the “perfect information” of economic theory. In the information environment of the 1950s and 1960s, cognitive limitations, limits on attention, and satisficing behavior were prevalent. In today’s business environment, however, managers have much more information and many more tools available for information management and decision making. Real-time information systems, marketing insight, forecasting systems, fast-response production systems, expert systems, crowdsourcing, and cloud computing, among other tools, are dramatically increasing managers’ information and its ex ante processing (we acknowledge that these tools can also create information overload issues). This increase in processed information and predictive abilities may move organizations toward a maximization and future expectations orientation. Furthermore, March’s 1991 article adds exploration search to the incremental exploitation search of behavioral theory. In so doing, he added the concept of large strategic changes to behavioral theory. In Ansoff’s strategic management view, managers are expected to goal seek more than maximize—acknowledging a tendency toward satisficing. Thus, in the long term, it may be possible for these views to converge into a unified theoretical framework.

sec.title: Satisficing (goal-directed) and strategically aggressive (goal-seeking) behavior
sec.p: There is an important but subtle distinction between behavioral theory and Ansoff’s perspectives about the determinants of aspiration levels. While behavioral theory suggests aspirations are incrementally updated to reflect past performance in a satisficing process (satisficing implies seeking to achieve one’s aspirations, which are not necessarily low), Ansoff (1979) argues aggressive, forward-looking, analytical planning by management plays an important role in determining aspiration levels. Ansoff (1979) suggests that one way to operationalize this behavior is to classify organizations on a strategic aggressiveness scale. More aggressive organizations identify and focus on opportunities to make dramatic improvements in performance and therefore set much higher goals than would be predicted by simply extrapolating prior performance. Originally, Ansoff (1979) used the term goal seeking to define the midpoint on a strategic aggressiveness scale (ranging from satisficing to maximization). Later, Ansoff developed five categories for strategic aggressiveness: stable, reactive, anticipatory, entrepreneurial, and creative (Ansoff, 1984; Moussetis, 2011). The Ansoffian view suggests heterogeneity across firms, in terms of strategically aggressive behavior, may explain departures from aspiration levels based only on history-based performance. We encourage scholars to empirically investigate Ansoff’s model. Such investigations could shed light on several questions raised by prior findings regarding striving aspirations, multiple aspirations, and proactive–reactive behavior. In this endeavor, scholars will need to rigorously derive precise definitions and specific predictions from the theories. We encourage them to design survey and interview approaches that will be relevant across different environments, industries, and contexts to tease out the difference between satisficing (goal-directed) and strategically aggressive (goal-seeking) behavior.

sec.title: Legitimacy theory
sec.p: We believe legitimacy theory may be a powerful lens to explore the antecedents of aspirations, especially publicly stated aspirations (Desai, 2008; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Greve, 2003c: 175). There are two perspectives on legitimacy—sociological institutional theory and strategic legitimacy theory. Sociological institutional theory generally considers society’s view of an organization based on constitutive beliefs and norms (DiMaggio & Powell, 1983), while strategic legitimacy theory considers that managers actively shape the view of an organization (Suchman, 1995). Short and Palmer (2003) indicate high-performing firms may use referents for self-enhancement and impression management—thus, in a strategic manner. Scholars should study how legitimacy theory may explain the selection of goal dimensions, referent groups for comparison, and aspiration levels. For example, while stakeholders may influence aspiration levels, might firms also establish aspiration levels to gain legitimacy with stakeholders? Does external communication of aspirations moderate the antecedent–aspiration relationship? Does sociological institutional theory (macro societal norms) better explain goal dimensions than coalition composition and problems described by behavioral theory?

sec.title: Psychological goal-setting theory
sec.p: The psychology literature on individual goal setting is highly developed and supported by more than 400 empirical studies across the globe (Locke & Latham, 2002, 2006). It is based on motivations in work settings and considers group and team goals (Locke & Latham, 2002, 2006). While caution is suggested in equating individual-level to organization-level behavior, insights may be fungible across this boundary.

Psychological goal-setting theory provides several factors that may have influence at the organizational level. The first factors are goal specificity and difficulty—specific, difficult goals lead to higher performance. Difficult performance goals increase the riskiness of the strategies selected (Locke & Latham, 2002), while achievable goals are more motivational (Fried & Slowik, 2004). Another factor that influences goals is self-efficacy—task-specific confidence. Finally, goal conflict studies suggest personal goals mediate assigned organizational goals and external incentives (Locke & Latham, 2002). In psychological goal-setting theory, goals affect performance through four mechanisms: (a) directive function—directing attention and effort, (b) energizing function—high goals lead to greater effort, (c) persistence—hard goals prolong effort, and (d) goals lead to the search for and use of task-relevant knowledge and strategies (Locke & Latham, 2002). There are several moderators of the goal–performance relationship. The first is commitment—the goal–performance relationship is strongest when people are committed to their goals. Goal commitment is related to importance of outcomes and self-efficacy. It is important to note that organizational aspiration levels correspond to goal acceptance, not goal commitment (Campion & Lord, 1982; Locke, Shaw, Saari, & Latham, 1981). The second moderator is feedback—clarity and specificity are salient. The third is task complexity—goal effects are dependent on the ability to discover appropriate task strategies. The fourth moderator is goal framing—“approach success” versus “avoid failure.” Fifth, higher level goals and organizational visions have been shown to moderate outcomes (J. R. Baum & Locke, 2004). Integrating psychological goal-setting theory with organizational aspirations may provide an increased ability to explain heterogeneity in both aspiration selection and consequences. For example, goal difficulty and goal commitment (strength of aspirations) appear particularly salient at the organizational level.
Research questions regarding theoretical framing include the following:

list-item.p: What terms should be added to Cyert and March’s (1963) formal model for aspiration levels?
Do organizations follow behavioral, strategic reference point, or Ansoffian views? Are there contingencies in which different views have higher explanatory power?
How much can we improve the explanatory power of relationships regarding organizational aspirations by adding aspects of other theories or integrating aspects of the three views?

sec.title: Antecedents
sec.p: Although scholars have identified several antecedents of aspirations beyond Cyert and March’s (1963) original model, it remains unclear which antecedents take precedence, and under what conditions they do so. “There has been a paucity of empirical work testing determinants of aspiration levels in field settings,” say Mezias et al. (2002: 1286). Short and Palmer (2003: 209) echo that sentiment by stating, “Theoretical and empirical development of performance referents in organizations has been sparse.” The study of antecedents presents a substantial challenge because to do so requires fine-grained firm-level data. Thus, our primary suggestion to future researchers is to perform survey and interview-based studies in the field. This will aid both theory and practice. We expound on this suggestion by offering research opportunities in four categories: performance, internal factors, external factors, and time.

sec.title: Performance
sec.p: Which performance referent is most important—past aspiration, past performance, or performance of others? Behavioral researchers have different views and results as discussed previously. Does the duration of aspiration attainment discrepancy matter as well as intensity, as argued by Haleblian and Rajagopalan (2005)? We believe that understanding the joint influence of intensity and duration may enlighten our knowledge of both performance referents and aspiration adjustment. In sum, additional analysis of how decision makers think about performance referents has high potential to contribute rich understanding.

Though highly researched, the referent group for social comparison remains unsettled. The majority of extant studies use industry averages for social performance comparison, suggesting all other organizations influence the focal organization (Greve, 2008; Short & Palmer, 2003). Yet referent groups, in theory, are those individual firms to which the focal firm compares itself (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996; Labianca et al., 2009). Provocatively, Lehner (2000: 75) states, “Future studies should address the question whether there are any firms that refer to the industry average or whether the explanatory power of this proxy is just a consequence of the existence of many similar individual reference levels near the median.” The remaining question is, which firms are the most influential comparators? Many researchers have called for increasing the precision and realism of performance feedback models by careful specification of the reference group definition (J. A. C. Baum & Dahlin, 2007; J. A. C. Baum et al., 2005; Labianca et al., 2009; Short & Palmer, 2003). We agree with these researchers and strongly urge scholars to explore the performance referents and reference groups used in practice.

sec.title: Internal factors
sec.p: Many organizational factors have been suggested as antecedents but remain untested. In this arena, scholars should explore the logic of micro foundations of organizational constructs (Felin & Foss, 2009) to better understand the origins and the level of intentionality of aspirations in organizational practice. First, recall that Cyert and March (1963) specified three variables that influence goal dimensions: coalitions, division of labor, and problems. Interestingly, we find no evidence of empirical work considering these factors. Since the strategic choice views do not separate goal dimensions from goal aspirations, there is an abundance of empirical questions left to answer in this distinction. Second, numerous internal factors have been proposed, as shown in Figure 1, including organizational culture–values, shared meanings, and traditions (Ansoff, 1979; Harris & Bromiley, 2007), leadership, extent of managerial discretion (Greve, 2003c: 181), and power distributions and bargaining processes (Ansoff, 1979; Harris & Bromiley, 2007). Third, capabilities are viewed as important (Ansoff, 1979; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). Since capabilities may influence both managerial cognition as well as ability to accomplish aspirations, scholars in this area should consider the cognition–capabilities debate (e.g., S. Kaplan, 2008). Given the centrality of capabilities in strategic management, understanding their influence is paramount. For example, how do capabilities influence aspirations? Do only current capabilities influence aspirations? In contrast to capabilities influencing aspirations, when do aspirations influence capability development? In total, we believe important research opportunities exist regarding internal organizational factors as antecedents to both aspiration levels and the strength of aspirations.

sec.title: External factors
sec.p: Little is known about the relevancy of external factors, such as environments and institutions, on aspirations. Researchers have long recognized environmental instability as a potential influence (Gooding et al., 1996; Levinthal & March, 1981). Yet behavioral theory anticipates that informed comparisons of past performance levels are possible. What do firms do in highly dynamic environments where past performance and peer performance may be difficult to interpret or uninformative? Similarly, how do different competitive contexts influence both aspiration levels and the strength of aspirations? We encourage scholars to consider how competition and competitive dynamics influence aspirations.

Ansoff (1987) discussed the influencing forces of the external legitimizing environment. This influence took the form of “expectations . . . placed by regulatory bodies on the strategic degrees of freedom; financial subsidies; rules of the game under which the organization must develop” (Ansoff, 1987: 513, emphasis original). This argument clearly acknowledges the influence of institutions. Institutional effects, both sociological and economic, are anticipated to be particularly relevant in studies that cross country borders (Mezias et al., 2002). Given the importance of cross-border business activities, understanding institutional influence on aspirations is an urgent matter. How predictive are existing models in different institutional contexts or changing institutional contexts?

sec.title: Time
sec.p: The time dimension in strategic reference point theory includes both past—learning and identity—and future—strategic intent (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). Future expectations of the environment are a critical part of Ansoff’s framework (Ansoff, 1979: 156). Grinyer and McKiernan (1990) argue aspiration levels are influenced by perceptions of new opportunities that realistically might be achieved. Iyer and Miller (2008) call for more studies on whether managers are more retrospective or prospective; in other words, problem driven or opportunity driven. In addition, Labianca et al. (2009) purport that choice of organizational referents is a cognitive process that incorporates future-oriented elements. In sum, the literature recognizes the potential influence of time—history, path dependency, traditions, future expectations, and future vision—but empirical evidence is extremely limited.

sec.title: Research questions regarding antecedents
sec.p: Our discussion regarding antecedents can be expanded, by interested scholars, through considerations of (a) the many factors proposed in Ansoff’s (1979, 1987) view of aspirations, (b) the building blocks of strategic reference point theory (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996), (c) Cyert and March’s (1963) factors influencing goal dimensions, and (d) psychological goal-setting theory. Two key challenges for scholars are (a) to distill the numerous factors that may influence aspirations to the few factors that do influence aspirations and (b) to determine the relative importance of those factors in various contexts and contingencies. The research questions regarding aspiration antecedents are numerous; they include, but are not limited to, the following:

list-item.p: To what extent are group or industry averages used as referents?

Which internal, external, and time factors are most important (e.g., organizational capabilities, competitive context, future expectations, attainment discrepancy duration, etc.)? Are these factors different for firms on performance frontiers (leading firms) or in different contexts?
Are the antecedents of aspiration levels analogous to the antecedents of strength of aspirations?
How much heterogeneity exists between firms in how they determine aspirations?

sec.title: Consequences
sec.p: Aspirations are helpful in explaining heterogeneous firm-level decision making, strategic behavior, and performance in an array of contexts and industries. However, our knowledge is incomplete. Greve (2008: 490) states, “Organizational responses to goals still define a research area where important questions remain unexplored.” Researchers have begun to expand the studied consequences, and this expansion will continue as aspirations beyond financial performance are considered.

The traditional consequence domain of aspiration studies has been strategically important organizational changes and decisions. However, this is not a theoretical constraint. We believe the consequences of aspirations should be considered more broadly to identify differences across types of consequences. Examples include, but are not limited to, lower level decisions, higher level decisions, such as corporate board decisions (Greve, 2003c), deviant or corrupt behaviors (Lehman & Ramanujam, 2009), operational behaviors, image building rather than substantive change (Harris & Bromiley, 2007), social decisions such as environmental sustainability, long-term decisions such as capability building, and nonstrategic behaviors. Scholars should ask, what outcomes may be informed by understanding aspirations? For example, Gary (2005) utilizes aspirations logic to support the understanding of resource sharing in corporate diversification. Furthermore, extant studies focus primarily on average firms. Only one empirical study considers firms on performance frontiers (Massini et al., 2005), although much can be learned from such firms.

Where will organizations change when aspirations are unmet? This remains a question that needs empirical exploration. Behavioral theory considers problem-driven search for alternative routines and expects change will be undertaken near the symptom, in areas with low power, and in areas that have recently changed (Cyert & March, 1963). In contrast, if a strategic thrust is determined necessary based on aspiration attainment discrepancy in the Ansoffian view, an array of factors can influence the choice of specific action. Psychology studies inform that difficult performance goals increase the riskiness of the strategies selected (Locke & Latham, 2002). However, existing theory is very limited in predicting the specific kinds of strategies firms will adopt. As such, we encourage scholars to jointly or comparatively consider Ansoff’s (1979) concepts regarding strategic thrusts and behavioral search theory to better understand the direction of search and the types of strategies firms may select conditioned on their goal difficulty and aspiration attainment.

Much of the work on aspirations examines risky decisions (risk is associated with change) and draws support from prospect theory. Recently, Bromiley (2010) admonished strategy researchers for misinterpreting prospect theory’s predictions and ignoring the full set of assumptions in the theory (also see Holmes, Bromiley, Devers, Holcomb, & McGuire, 2011). Bromiley (2010: 1359) provocatively states, “The most obvious interpretation of prospect theory would imply firm performance has no influence on risk taking.” Central to his argument is that prospect theory assumes decision makers face choices in isolation and that most choices will be mixed gambles—both assumptions are typically ignored in extant strategy research. He demonstrates that prospect theory’s predictions vary with all of its parameters, reference points, and characteristics of the choices involved. This admonishment calls into question some of the past work and creates a need for further research.
Research questions regarding consequences include the following:

list-item.p: What is the range of influence of aspirations on firm behavior?
How do aspirations shape the lower level, nonstrategic choices of organizations?
How do aspirations influence firms on performance frontiers, in contrast to firms that are average?
How do aspiration attainment discrepancy and strength of aspirations influence the direction of search, magnitude of change, and types of strategies firms select?

sec.title: Moderators
sec.p: We believe improved understanding of moderators will help reconcile unexpected results attributed to unobserved organizational heterogeneity. Beyond moderation models, researchers are also encouraged to consider mediation models following the works of Audia, Locke, and Smith (2000) and J. R. Baum and Locke (2004), as well as combining mediation and moderation (see Mathieu, DeShon, & Bergh, 2008). Many of the factors identified as moderators, such as leadership, country culture, and goal commitment, could also be mediators. Furthermore, as scholars explore this area they should also consider how these factors moderate or mediate the antecedent–aspiration relationship. For example, past performance–aspiration relationships may be moderated by environmental factors. Moderators provide an opportunity-rich area for future research, including internal factors, external factors, and cognitive and psychological factors following Figure 1. We acknowledge moderators of the aspiration–consequence relationship may be lacking in generalizability because those relationships vary across different outcomes. However, researchers should seek to discover if a key set of moderators are generalizable.

sec.title: Internal factors
sec.p: The aspiration–consequence relationship includes aspects of organizational change implementation, introducing numerous complex contingencies. We refer the reader to the discussion on antecedents regarding organizational factors and leadership since these may also moderate the aspiration–consequence relationship (e.g., capabilities and culture). The literature frequently mentions systems and structures, including compensation and incentive systems (Harris & Bromiley, 2007; Meyer, 2002), internal politics (Greve, 1998), approaches to control (Eisenhardt, 1985), and governance (Iyer & Miller, 2008). Researchers are encouraged to consider the processes firms use when establishing or altering aspirations as potential moderators. For example, Fiegenbaum et al. (1996) mention the level of consensus regarding aspirations. Importantly, understanding the influence of other controllable contingencies could have a substantial impact on managerial practice.

As mentioned previously, multiple aspirations may interact. Cyert and March (1963) indicate organizations consider performance in multiple goal dimensions including production, inventory, sales, market share, and profitability. Ansoff (1984: 140) identifies multiple aspirations across various categories: society, community, shareholders, lenders, customers, managers, and employees. He argues firms prioritize such aspirations and profit is not always the primary aspiration. Subsequently, R. S. Kaplan and Norton (1996a, 1996b, 2001) introduced the “balanced scorecard,” which establishes four categories—financial, customer, learning and growth, and internal business processes—with multiple goals in each. The balanced scorecard approach is widely utilized in practice, and it is now common for firms to have more than 50 top-level goals in addition to subgoals by function (Meyer, 2002), as well as stretch goals and learning goals (Seijts & Latham, 2005). While Cyert and March (1963) suggest sequential attention to goals and Ansoff (1979) suggests priority or hierarchy, only a limited amount of empirical work has addressed the issue (although accounting literature gives it some consideration; see, e.g., Cheng, Luckett, & Mahama, 2007; Ittner, Larcker, & Meyer, 2003; Lipe & Salterio, 2000). How do managers and organizations deal with such large goal sets (more than 50 top-level goals) in practice? The manner in which complex sets of goals interact to influence multiple consequences is an area that deserves research attention.

sec.title: External factors
sec.p: External factors, such as competitive contexts, country cultural institutions, and economic institutions (e.g., regulatory regimes), may be moderators of the aspiration–consequence relationship. For example, Grinyer and McKiernan (1990) propose a theoretical model where organizational change is influenced by the actions and pressures of external stakeholders on aspirations. As a second example, our understanding of the motivations from aspirations is based on developed economies, and most studies concern a single country (Mezias et al., 2002). Grouzet et al. (2005) indicate countries’ cultures influence goal aspirations (goal importance) at an individual level. Thus, it is likely that the aspiration–consequence relationship will vary across countries and cultures, yet this remains an open empirical question.

sec.title: Cognitive and psychological factors
sec.p: Only a cursory examination of cognitive and psychological factors, as moderators, has been performed to date. This is surprising because (a) aspirations have a large cognitive component (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996), (b) cognition has been recognized in strategic decision making for more than two decades (Eisenhardt & Zbaracki, 1992; Gary & Wood, 2011; Reger & Huff, 1993), and (c) perceptions of future states are recognized to affect present actions at the individual level (Bandura, 1997). While self-efficacy perceptions have been studied (Audia et al., 2000), other perceptions, such as perceived level of controllability (Lant & Shapira, 2008), anticipation of future environmental changes (Greve, 1998), attributions (Haleblian & Rajagopalan, 2005), competitor cognition (Greve, 2003c), and permanence (Haleblian & Rajagopalan, 2005), have been proposed but not rigorously studied. Cognition is expected to moderate the aspiration–consequence relationship by influencing both implementation and the framing of issues (Ansoff, 1979; Fiegenbaum et al., 1996).

Integrating concepts from psychological goal-setting theory provides a large set of potential moderators that may enhance understanding of outcome heterogeneity. The focus of psychological goal-setting theory is on the core properties of an effective goal—in terms of achieving the desired performance outcome. These core properties may be moderators in the aspiration–consequence relationship since they influence the strength of the relationship. These core properties include goal difficulty, goal complexity, goal commitment, goal framing, goal alignment or conflict (also mentioned by Fiegenbaum et al., 1996), and congruence with the organizational vision (Locke & Latham, 2002, 2006). For example, when aspirations are publically stated, the commitment to the aspiration may be influenced (Meyer, 2002).

sec.title: Research questions regarding moderators
sec.p: While our focus in this section is moderators of the aspiration–consequence relationship, we acknowledge these factors may also be moderators in the antecedent–aspiration relationship, or they may be mediators in either of these relationships. Research questions to initiate scholarly investigation include the following:

list-item.p: What is the magnitude of the moderating effects of internal and external factors such as capabilities, leadership, and competitive context on the aspirations–consequence relationship?
How do multiple goals interact to influence consequences and multiple consequences?
In cross-country or multi-industry studies, which factors are the most important moderators?
How can cognition and psychological goal-setting theory inform our understanding of the consequences of organizational aspirations?

sec.title: Adaptation and Learning
sec.p: Aspirations are adapted over time. How firms alter their aspirations, in practice, could provide much insight into aspiration theory, yet “there has been very little research on aspiration-level adjustment rules” (Greve, 2002: 13). If decision makers utilize heuristics (Eisenhardt & Zbaracki, 1992) in such aspiration-level adjustment situations, understanding their structures and sources could provide a substantial contribution. There is also little field research on adjustment rates. Researchers in this area should consider the literature on expectations as it may provide additional insights (e.g., Lomi, Larsen, & Wezel, 2010). We encourage scholars to study how managers adjust aspirations in organizational contexts since aspiration adjustment rates, mechanisms, and heuristics are not well understood. Potential research questions regarding the adaptation of aspirations include the following:

list-item.p: What factors and contingencies affect the speed of adjustment of aspirations?
What heuristics affect the adjustment of aspirations? How are these heuristics established?

sec.title: Data
sec.p: We believe scholars should make investments in primary data collection to increase understanding of the phenomenon and to enable comparative examinations of the different theoretical views. This requires direct measurement of aspiration levels over time, detailed surveys, interviews, and qualitative approaches to clarify processes of aspiration formation and the influence of aspirations on decision making. We are not the first to make such suggestions (e.g., Greve, 2002, 2003c; Labianca et al., 2009). These requirements could be supplemented by field experiments, quasi-experiments, and studies in laboratory settings. We urge scholars to seek deeper understanding of the cognitive, behavioral, and rational decision-making processes regarding aspiration selection and response. Scholars will require such information, as well as rigorous analyses of the theories and their mechanisms, to perform comparative analyses of the theoretical views.

Scholars have gained much insight through the analysis of archival data sets using behavioral theory’s formal model of aspirations. At the same time, such archival-based methodologies limit scholars’ understanding of the phenomenon, are prone to local biases (i.e., reference group selection), and leave many debates unresolved. In addition, scholars have been able to evaluate only a limited number of theorized factors because of data set constraints. We wonder how data availability may have influenced the field and offer two possible explanations for the focus of extant literature on the behavioral view. The first is that scholars may view the behavioral approach as the most powerful way to explain aspirations since it is part of a more complete theory of the firm. The second is that this focus may be the result of the formal model, which allows aspirations to be inferred from preexisting archival data. While the second explanation is conjecture, we discovered three supportive points: (a) limited field studies of aspiration levels in the behavioral view that reaffirm the formal model, (b) calls for increases in field studies by behavioral theorists (see, e.g., Greve, 2002, 2003c; Labianca et al., 2009), and (c) lack of studies considering the second aspect of Cyert and March’s (1963) theory, namely, the factors influencing goal dimensions that require detailed, firm-specific information. Despite which explanation is supported, a tremendous foundation from these archival studies is now in place. Therefore, we call on scholars to move beyond theoretically inferred aspiration levels toward field measurements in organizational settings.

sec.title: Modeling
sec.p: Aspiration researchers use various analytical techniques depending on the specifics of the study and data structure. Our review identifies one aspect of aspiration-specific modeling that is in debate. Researchers utilize different modeling approaches in their consideration of historical and social aspirations. Cyert and March (1963: 115) specified the joint effects as “some weighted function of the three variables” (including past aspiration). More recently, researchers have specified four ways: (a) treat the two variables separately (Iyer & Miller, 2008), (b) select the weight coefficients providing the best model fit (Greve, 2003a), (c) specify a negative inconsistency parameter (Greve, 1998), and (d) specify an interaction (J. A. C. Baum et al., 2005). It is noteworthy that empirical results based on those four alternative approaches may contradict each other. Furthermore, Harris and Bromiley (2007) observe historical and social comparisons triggering different responses. This suggests firms may have two distinct aspirations—one relative to self-comparison and one relative to social comparison. Therefore, we encourage scholars to motivate their selected approach and to provide sensitivity studies comparing the various approaches. This will provide a more complete understanding and enable future meta-analyses across studies.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Measurement issues regarding aspiration studies are challenging. And as researchers move toward field investigations, these measurement challenges are likely to increase. Fortunately, the related literature from economics and psychology provides helpful approaches regarding several important measurement issues. Thus, we limit our comments here to major concerns.

First, the proper measurement of aspirations is critical to enhanced understanding. Yet little guidance exists on how to identify and precisely measure them, particularly in field settings (Holmes et al., 2011). Researchers have used a variety of approaches. For example, sales target (Lant, 1992; Lant & Montgomery, 1987; Mezias et al., 2002), sales and employment target (J. R. Baum & Locke, 2004), and growth aspiration index using a four-item factor based on sales and employment targets (Wiklund & Shepherd, 2003) have all been employed. However, existing work is founded on the premise that researchers understand how managers interpret aspirations. We believe this premise is questionable, but particularly so in the case of multiple aspirations—which applies to most organizations. The key question is, which aspirations influence which consequences? And why? For example, are only explicit, documented aspirations relevant? If implicit aspirations are also relevant, how are they to be determined? In such situations, Holmes et al. (2011) remind us of the importance of “framing” in the understanding of managerial decisions. Fiegenbaum et al. (1996: 223) captured this by stating, “Studies indicate that any variable(s) that highlights a particular target or objective seems capable of establishing a reference point and subsequently, of creating a decision frame.” This perspective adds credence to the relevance of detailed field studies. To understand managers’ cognitive frames regarding goal setting, many complex contingencies will need to be considered. For example, framing may be relevant in situations where decision makers both negotiate goals and anticipate rewards for accomplishment of those self-negotiated goals. Furthermore, as researchers investigate firm-level heterogeneity in aspiration choices, empirical techniques to address endogeneity will be pertinent (see Bascle, 2008).

Second, scholars need to consider levels of analysis. Who makes the decisions regarding aspirations, and how are they made? A substantial literature argues individual managers have different aspirations (Ethiraj & Levinthal, 2009; Haleblian & Rajagopalan, 2005; Short & Palmer, 2003). While scholars may address the measurement of aspiration levels and the strength of aspirations as organizational values (Alwin & Krosnick, 1985; Fischer, 2004), this approach assumes averages represent the organizational construct. Such assumptions create potential cross-level fallacies (e.g., Rousseau, 1985). We encourage scholars to identify decision makers and account for the processes used in determining aspirations and responses. Fascinating insights may be gained by considering the differences in views of top managers and the decision processes and culture of the organization. A substantial contribution could be made by defining a context-free approach to measure organization-level aspirations and the commitment to them.

Third, the measurement of consequences needs more detailed consideration. Rather than absolute values, a baseline for changes in consequences should be established in studies of behavior (Ketchen & Palmer, 1999). In other words, researchers should strive to understand “normal behavior” to better assess the meaning of observed “changed behavior.” Specifically, we should measure behavioral change relative to the historical trend of the organization. In addition, the majority of studies equate change with risk without understanding the risk perceptions of the decision makers (see Holmes et al., 2011). For example, not only may some changes not be risky, but also, in some cases, changing may be less risky than not changing. We encourage scholars to better understand both the magnitude of change and the perceptions of change of the decision makers.

Fourth, time is a factor with important influences (Fiegenbaum et al., 1996). How do managers think about time in an organizational setting? As managers define aspirations, adapt them, and respond to attainment discrepancies, are their considerations short term or long term, do they include expectations of organizational response delays, and are they reactive or proactive? What are the joint effects of time and environmental turbulence (Ansoff, 1979; Moussetis, 2011)? Longitudinal research designs may provide insights into how organizations adapt aspirations over time. We encourage scholars to develop a better understanding of the influence of time in the process of aspiration formation, adaptation, and response.

Last, we believe, in many situations, it is important to understand both the level of an aspiration and the commitment to accomplish that aspiration. Mezias et al. (2002: 1289) hint at this concern, noting that using aspirations, in behavioral theory, implies additional assumptions “that participants perceive the specific aspirations as important, and are motivated to achieve them.” The important distinction among aspiration level, attainment discrepancy, and commitment (strength) has received scant attention. As an example of the types of measures used for aspiration strength, Cavusgil and Nevin (1981) asked managers the importance of specific goals for their firm on a 0 to 100 scale. Scholars should consider insights gained from psychological studies of individual goal acceptance and goal commitment. We believe the commitment to achieve a particular aspiration level—the organizational strength of aspiration—may be pertinent in studies where attainment discrepancy does not directly and uniformly relate to commitment. Such situations likely include cross-country, cross-cultural, and cross-industry studies, as well as multiple goal contexts.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: This is the first attempt to synthesize the understanding of organizational aspirations across theoretical views and literatures. Our analysis suggests the behavioral view can be extended by integrating additional factors and by empirically testing the goal dimensions aspect of the theory. The strategic choice views will benefit from increased empirical testing, including assessing the importance of firm-level heterogeneity in aspiration selection and response. Most importantly, the comprehensive understanding presented herein provides a renewed starting point for the continued scholarly investigation of aspirations.

Our review of the organizational aspirations literature highlights the tremendous progress of the field. Yet important research opportunities remain. We have outlined a research agenda that we believe will build a more informed understanding of organizational aspirations. Our hope is that this enhanced understanding will lead to improved knowledge and improved managerial guidance.

Ansoff uses two terms in a different way than behavioral theory—goal seeking and satisficing. To distinguish the first, we use goal directed for behavioral theory and goal seeking for the Ansoffian view. Second, Ansoff argues satisficing is a low level of accomplishment motivation, whereas behavioral theory considers satisficing as the process of seeking to achieve one’s aspirations. While these concepts are similar across theoretical views, they are not analogous. In behavioral theory, goal directedness includes adaptation of aspirations, sequential attention, acceptable level decision rules, local rationality, and quasi-resolution of conflict. The Ansoffian view has no equivalent processes; it considers strategic choice processes of managers based on perceived needs.
